A well-documented example is the circadian gating of ABA-induced stomatal closure. Stomata are most responsive to ABA during the subjective day, when transpiration demand is highest and regulation is most needed. The molecular basis involves clock-regulated expression of ABA signaling components: SLAC1 (slow anion channel, required for ABA-induced stomatal closure) transcript levels peak during the day under clock control. Similarly, the expression of ABA receptors (PYR/PYL/RCAR family), SnRK2 kinases, and other signaling intermediates shows circadian oscillation. The transcription factor TOC1/PRR1 directly binds to ABAR/CHLH (a putative ABA receptor) promoter. ABA itself can also provide input to the clock through modulation of PRR5, PRR7, and TOC1 expression. Other examples of circadian gating include: clock-gated cold acclimation (CBF gene induction is stronger when cold occurs at subjective dawn), clock-gated pathogen defense (resistance to Pseudomonas peaks at subjective dawn), and clock-gated growth (hypocotyl elongation is gated to occur during subjective evening/night through PIF4/PIF5 clock regulation).

questions.question: Gibberellin-mediated stem elongation involves both cell division and cell elongation in the subapical meristem and elongation zone. What is the specific cellular mechanism by which GA promotes cell elongation?
options: GA directly activates expansin proteins by binding to them as an allosteric cofactor
GA increases turgor pressure by stimulating potassium channel expression, and the increased turgor alone is sufficient for elongation without wall loosening

GA promotes cell elongation through DELLA degradation, which releases growth-promoting PIF transcription factors that activate genes for cell wall-loosening enzymes (expansins, XTHs), stimulate auxin biosynthesis (YUC genes), and promote cortical microtubule reorientation from longitudinal to transverse, enabling anisotropic cell expansion
GA triggers endoreduplication (DNA synthesis without cell division), and the increased nuclear size physically expands cells
questions.explanation: GA-promoted stem elongation involves multiple coordinated cellular processes that are largely DELLA-dependent. In the absence of GA, DELLA proteins (RGA, GAI, RGL1-3 in Arabidopsis) sequester growth-promoting transcription factors, particularly PIFs (PIF3, PIF4) and other bHLH proteins. When GA triggers DELLA degradation via the GID1-SCF(SLY1) pathway, these transcription factors are released. The released PIFs and other factors then: (1) Activate expression of cell wall-loosening enzymes including expansins (EXPA1, EXPA8) that disrupt hydrogen bonds between cellulose and hemicellulose, and xyloglucan endotransglucosylase/hydrolases (XTHs) that cleave and relink xyloglucan chains. (2) Promote auxin biosynthesis by upregulating YUC8 and other YUCCA genes, which further contributes to cell elongation through the acid growth mechanism. (3) Promote reorientation of cortical microtubules from longitudinal to transverse orientation. Since cellulose synthase complexes (CESA) track along cortical microtubules, transverse microtubules direct cellulose microfibril deposition in transverse hoops, restricting radial expansion and channeling turgor-driven growth into longitudinal (axial) cell elongation. (4) Activate aquaporin expression for enhanced water uptake. (5) Promote cell cycle progression in subapical meristems through D-type cyclin activation. The integration of wall loosening, turgor, and cytoskeletal reorientation provides the full mechanism for GA-stimulated stem elongation.

questions.question: Mycorrhiza-induced resistance (MIR) is a form of plant immune priming triggered by mycorrhizal symbiosis. How does MIR differ from classical SAR and ISR?
options: MIR is identical to SAR in all molecular aspects, requiring SA and PR gene expression
MIR does not involve any known defense signaling pathway and instead relies exclusively on physical strengthening of the root cell wall by fungal chitin deposits

MIR involves priming of JA-dependent defense responses by arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, similar to ISR but with additional contributions from the mycorrhiza-specific signaling pathway involving strigolactones and the common symbiosis signaling pathway (CSSP/DMI genes)
MIR suppresses all plant immunity to allow the mycorrhizal fungus to colonize without resistance, increasing pathogen susceptibility
questions.explanation: Mycorrhiza-induced resistance (MIR) is a distinct form of induced resistance that shares features with ISR but has unique components related to the mycorrhizal symbiosis. Like ISR (induced by PGPR), MIR primarily primes JA/ET-dependent defense pathways rather than SA-dependent PR gene expression. Plants colonized by arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) show enhanced resistance to root and shoot pathogens and even some herbivores, without constitutive activation of defense genes. Instead, defense responses are primed—they are activated faster and stronger upon subsequent pathogen challenge. The unique aspects of MIR include: (1) The Common Symbiosis Signaling Pathway (CSSP), shared with rhizobial nodulation, involves DMI1 (calcium channel), DMI2 (receptor kinase), and CCaMK/DMI3 (calcium-calmodulin-dependent kinase) that decode the nuclear calcium oscillations triggered by mycorrhizal Myc factors. (2) Strigolactone exudation from roots, which promotes AMF hyphal branching and colonization, also modulates defense priming. (3) Mycorrhizal colonization triggers moderate JA accumulation and changes in the JA/SA balance. (4) Callose deposition and cell wall reinforcement at arbuscular interfaces may contribute to physical defense enhancement. (5) Mycorrhizal networks can transmit defense signals between connected plants (common mycorrhizal networks). MIR does not suppress immunity—rather, the plant carefully regulates its immune responses to tolerate the beneficial fungus while maintaining pathogen resistance.

questions.question: Epinasty (downward leaf curling) is a classic ethylene-mediated response observed in waterlogged plants. What causes ethylene accumulation during flooding, and how does it lead to adaptive aerenchyma formation?
options: Flooding suppresses ethylene production, and aerenchyma forms through cell division rather than cell death
Ethylene is absorbed from the atmosphere into floodwater and passively enters roots; aerenchyma forms by mechanical rupture of cortical cells under water pressure

Flooding increases ethylene biosynthesis in roots (ACC synthase is induced by hypoxia), but the slow diffusion of ethylene through water prevents its escape, causing accumulation; accumulated ethylene then triggers programmed cell death in cortical cells through lysigenous aerenchyma formation mediated by ROS production via RBOH NADPH oxidase, creating gas channels for oxygen transport to submerged roots
Ethylene has no role in aerenchyma formation; the process is controlled entirely by ABA signaling during drought stress
questions.explanation: Flooding triggers ethylene accumulation through two complementary mechanisms: (1) Increased biosynthesis: Hypoxia (low O2) in waterlogged roots stabilizes Group VII ERF transcription factors (via the N-degron pathway), which induce ACC synthase (ACS) gene expression. Additionally, anaerobic conditions promote ACS activity. (2) Physical entrapment: Ethylene is a gaseous hormone that normally diffuses rapidly from plant tissues into the atmosphere. However, its diffusion rate through water is ~10,000 times slower than through air, so ethylene produced by submerged roots accumulates to high concentrations within the tissue. The accumulated ethylene triggers several adaptive responses: Epinasty occurs because ethylene causes differential growth of the petiole (greater cell elongation on the upper/adaxial side), curling the leaf downward. In roots, ethylene triggers lysigenous aerenchyma formation: ethylene activates RBOHD (NADPH oxidase) in specific cortical cells, producing reactive oxygen species (superoxide and H2O2). These ROS, combined with ethylene-induced metacaspase and nuclease activity, trigger programmed cell death (PCD) specifically in cortical cells in a spatially precise pattern. The dead cells are lysed, creating gas-filled lacunae (aerenchyma) that form continuous channels from the shoot (where oxygen is available) to the root tips, providing an internal aeration pathway. This is the primary adaptation of rice and other flood-tolerant species. Ethylene also promotes adventitious root formation and shoot elongation in deep-water rice (via internode GA/DELLA signaling activated by SNORKEL ERF genes).

questions.question: UV-B perception in plants is mediated by UVR8 (UV RESISTANCE LOCUS 8). What is unique about UVR8 as a photoreceptor compared to other plant photoreceptors?
options: UVR8 is a kinase that autophosphorylates upon UV-B exposure, identical in mechanism to phototropins
UVR8 uses retinal as its chromophore, similar to animal rhodopsins

UVR8 uses intrinsic tryptophan residues as the UV-B-absorbing chromophore instead of an extrinsic prosthetic group; UV-B absorption disrupts salt bridges between tryptophan residues at the homodimer interface, causing monomerization that enables interaction with COP1 to activate UV-B-responsive gene expression
UVR8 is a membrane-bound receptor that triggers calcium influx as its primary signaling mechanism
questions.explanation: UVR8 is unique among known photoreceptors because it uses intrinsic amino acid residues rather than an extrinsic chromophore (prosthetic group) for light absorption. While phytochromes use phytochromobilin, phototropins use FMN, and cryptochromes use FAD, UVR8 uses specific tryptophan residues (particularly Trp-233 and Trp-285) arranged at its homodimer interface. In the dark, UVR8 exists as a homodimer stabilized by electrostatic interactions (salt bridges) between charged residues (Arg, Asp) at the dimer interface, with tryptophan indole rings forming cation-pi interactions. UV-B photons (280-315 nm) are absorbed primarily by these interfacial tryptophan residues. The absorption causes excited-state electron transfer from Trp to neighboring Arg residues, neutralizing the salt bridges and disrupting the cation-pi interactions. This triggers rapid monomerization (within seconds of UV-B exposure). Monomeric UVR8 exposes surfaces that interact with COP1 WD40 domain. Remarkably, while COP1 normally functions as a negative regulator of photomorphogenesis (degrading HY5), the UVR8-COP1 interaction converts COP1 into a positive regulator: the complex stabilizes HY5 and activates UV-B-responsive genes, including flavonoid biosynthesis (CHS, CHI), phenylpropanoid pathway, and DNA repair (photolyase) genes. Re-dimerization of UVR8 (mediated by RUP1/RUP2 proteins) terminates signaling. The tryptophan-based perception mechanism makes UVR8 one of the most ancient photoreceptor types.

questions.question: The concept of hormonal homeostasis includes both biosynthesis and deactivation pathways. For auxin (IAA), what are the major routes of deactivation?
options: IAA is exclusively deactivated by oxidative catabolism through peroxidases, producing indole-3-aldehyde as the sole end product
IAA cannot be deactivated and instead accumulates indefinitely, with plants relying solely on reducing biosynthesis to lower auxin levels

IAA is deactivated through conjugation to amino acids (IAA-Asp, IAA-Glu are irreversible; IAA-Ala, IAA-Leu are reversible storage forms) by GH3 acyl acid amido synthetases, and through oxidation to 2-oxindole-3-acetic acid (oxIAA) by DIOXYGENASE FOR AUXIN OXIDATION (DAO) enzymes; these pathways work together to maintain IAA homeostasis
IAA is transported out of the plant entirely through root exudation as the only mechanism of removal
questions.explanation: Auxin homeostasis requires precise balance between biosynthesis, transport, and multiple deactivation mechanisms. The major deactivation pathways are: (1) Amino acid conjugation by GH3 family proteins: GH3 acyl acid amido synthetases catalyze the ATP-dependent conjugation of IAA to amino acids. This produces two types of conjugates: irreversible conjugates (IAA-Asp, IAA-Glu)—these mark IAA for catabolism and are the primary route for permanent IAA removal. Reversible conjugates (IAA-Ala, IAA-Leu, IAA-Phe)—these serve as storage forms that can be hydrolyzed back to free IAA by IAA-amino acid hydrolases (ILR1/ILL family) when needed, providing a buffering mechanism. (2) Oxidative catabolism by DAO (DIOXYGENASE FOR AUXIN OXIDATION) enzymes: DAO1 and DAO2 are 2-oxoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases that directly oxidize free IAA to 2-oxindole-3-acetic acid (oxIAA), which can be further conjugated to oxIAA-Glc by UDP-glucosyltransferases. The dao1 mutant accumulates excess IAA and shows auxin-overproduction phenotypes. (3) Glucosylation: IAA can be conjugated to glucose by UGT84B1 and other glucosyltransferases, forming IAA-glucose ester conjugates (reversible storage). (4) Methyl esterification: IAMT1 converts IAA to methyl-IAA (MeIAA), a volatile and membrane-permeable transport form. These multiple deactivation mechanisms provide fine-grained spatial and temporal control of active IAA levels.

questions.question: Systemic wound signaling in plants involves multiple mobile signals acting at different speeds. What is the correct order of signal propagation speed from fastest to slowest?
options: Phloem-mobile peptides > electrical signals > volatile compounds > hydraulic signals
All wound signals travel at the same speed through the vascular system

Electrical signals/calcium waves (~1-10 cm/s) > ROS wave (~0.14 cm/s) > hydraulic pressure wave (~variable) > phloem-mobile JA/JA-Ile (~0.01-0.03 cm/s) > volatile organic compounds (distance-dependent diffusion)
Volatile compounds > electrical signals > hydraulic signals > chemical signals in all cases
questions.explanation: Systemic wound signaling involves a hierarchy of mobile signals with different propagation speeds, ranges, and functions: (1) Electrical signals and calcium waves are the fastest, propagating at approximately 1-10 cm/s through the vasculature. Action potentials (APs) and variation potentials (VPs) travel through phloem-associated cells, with calcium waves propagating through GLR3.3/GLR3.6 channel-mediated relay. These provide the earliest warning to distal tissues (within seconds to minutes). (2) The ROS (RBOHD-mediated) wave travels at approximately 8.4 cm/min (~0.14 cm/s), propagating through apoplastic H2O2 and cell-to-cell RBOHD activation relay. This is coupled with the calcium wave and provides sustained signaling. (3) Hydraulic pressure waves can travel rapidly but are variable depending on tissue hydraulic conductivity. These involve pressure changes in the xylem caused by wound-induced water release. (4) Phloem-mobile chemical signals (JA, JA-Ile, OPDA, systemin peptide in Solanaceae, Pip/NHP for SAR) travel at phloem translocation speeds (~0.01-0.03 cm/s in Arabidopsis), arriving at distal leaves within 30-120 minutes. (5) Volatile organic compounds (MeJA, MeSA, GLVs) depend on gaseous diffusion and air movement, with effectiveness declining rapidly with distance. The integration of these multiple signal types ensures both rapid initial alerting and sustained, specific defense activation.

questions.question: Heavy metal tolerance in plants involves phytochelatins. What is the biosynthesis and function of phytochelatins in heavy metal detoxification?
options: Phytochelatins are small proteins encoded by specific PC genes that are transcriptionally induced by heavy metals
Phytochelatins are RNA aptamers that bind heavy metal ions in the cytoplasm and target them for excretion through the root epidermis
Phytochelatins are lipid-based chelators that bind heavy metals in the plasma membrane, preventing their entry into the cell

Phytochelatins are enzymatically synthesized peptides with the general structure (gamma-Glu-Cys)n-Gly, produced from glutathione by phytochelatin synthase (PCS); they bind heavy metal ions (especially Cd2+, As3+, Hg2+) through their thiol groups and transport the complexes into the vacuole via ABC transporters for sequestration
questions.explanation: Phytochelatins (PCs) are a family of thiol-rich peptides that are the primary mechanism for heavy metal detoxification in plants, fungi, and some animals. They have the general structure (gamma-Glu-Cys)n-Gly where n = 2-11 (most commonly 2-5). Unlike proteins, PCs are not ribosomally synthesized; they are produced enzymatically by phytochelatin synthase (PCS, encoded by PCS1 and PCS2 in Arabidopsis). PCS is a gamma-glutamylcysteine dipeptidyl transpeptidase that uses glutathione (gamma-Glu-Cys-Gly) as substrate, catalyzing the transfer of gamma-Glu-Cys units onto glutathione or existing PCs to build longer chains. PCS is constitutively expressed but is post-translationally activated by heavy metal ions (the metal ion binds to a regulatory domain, activating the enzyme). The multiple cysteine thiol groups in PCs form high-affinity coordination complexes with soft heavy metal ions, especially Cd2+, As3+, Pb2+, Hg2+, and Cu+. The PC-metal complexes (low-molecular-weight complexes, LMW) are transported into the vacuole by ABCC1/ABCC2 (ABC-type) transporters. In the vacuole, additional sulfide ions (from sulfide pathway) are incorporated to form high-molecular-weight (HMW) complexes that are more stable. Vacuolar sequestration effectively removes toxic metals from the cytoplasm. PCS knockout mutants (pcs1/cad1) are hypersensitive to cadmium and arsenic, confirming the essential role of PCs in metal tolerance.

questions.question:
Match each mutant phenotype with the affected hormone signaling component:
1. Constitutive triple response in the dark (short thick hypocotyl, exaggerated hook)
2. Extremely tall stems, pale green leaves (resembles GA-treated plants)
3. Bushy plant with excessive axillary branch outgrowth
4. Viviparous germination (seeds germinate on the parent ear)

A. Loss of DELLA proteins (GA signaling repressors)
B. ctr1 loss-of-function (constitutive ethylene signaling)
C. max3/max4 (strigolactone biosynthesis) loss-of-function
D. vp1/abi3 (ABA signaling) loss-of-function
questions.explanation: Each mutant phenotype is diagnostic for disruption of a specific hormone signaling pathway: (1) Constitutive triple response: The triple response (short hypocotyl, radial swelling, exaggerated hook) normally occurs only in the presence of ethylene. CTR1 is a Raf-like kinase that NEGATIVELY regulates ethylene signaling. In ctr1 loss-of-function mutants, ethylene signaling is constitutively active regardless of ethylene presence, producing the triple response even in darkness without ethylene. (2) Tall stems, pale leaves: This resembles plants treated with excess gibberellin. DELLA proteins are growth repressors that are normally degraded by GA signaling. Loss of DELLA function (e.g., quadruple della mutant in Arabidopsis, or slender rice1) mimics constitutive GA signaling, producing tall, slender plants with elongated internodes and reduced chlorophyll. The GA-insensitive wheat varieties of the Green Revolution carry gain-of-function DELLA mutations (Rht). (3) Excessive branching: Strigolactones inhibit axillary bud outgrowth. max3 (CCD7) and max4 (CCD8) encode carotenoid cleavage dioxygenases required for strigolactone biosynthesis. Loss of these genes eliminates strigolactone production, releasing all axillary buds from dormancy and producing extremely bushy plants. (4) Viviparous germination (vivipary): ABA maintains seed dormancy and prevents premature germination. VP1/ABI3 (VIVIPAROUS1/ABA INSENSITIVE 3) is a B3-domain transcription factor essential for ABA signaling during seed maturation. vp1 (maize) and abi3 (Arabidopsis) mutants fail to establish dormancy, and seeds germinate precociously on the parent plant (viviparous phenotype).

questions.question: Thermomorphogenesis is the adjustment of plant growth in response to warm (non-stressful) temperature. How does warm temperature promote hypocotyl elongation in Arabidopsis?
options: Warm temperature directly activates gibberellin biosynthesis genes independently of any thermosensor, and GA alone drives elongation
Thermomorphogenesis is entirely cryptochrome-dependent, with blue light sensitivity increasing at warm temperatures
Warm temperature triggers membrane depolarization that opens stretch-activated channels, and the resulting turgor increase alone drives hypocotyl elongation

Warm temperature (27-28 C) promotes PIF4 accumulation and activity through multiple mechanisms: phyB thermal reversion (Pfr to Pr) releases PIF4 from degradation, ELF3 (Evening Complex component) phase-separates and loses activity at warm temperatures, and PIF4 directly activates auxin biosynthesis (YUC8) and brassinosteroid signaling genes to drive elongation
questions.explanation: Thermomorphogenesis in Arabidopsis involves the integration of multiple thermosensory inputs converging on PIF4 (PHYTOCHROME INTERACTING FACTOR 4) as a central hub. The mechanisms include: (1) Phytochrome B thermal reversion: phyB Pfr (active form) undergoes faster thermal reversion to Pr (inactive form) at warm temperatures. At 27-28 C, Pfr reverts ~2x faster than at 22 C, reducing nuclear Pfr levels and allowing PIF4 to escape degradation and accumulate. This makes phyB a molecular thermosensor. (2) Evening Complex inactivation: The Evening Complex (EC: ELF3-ELF4-LUX) normally represses PIF4 transcription at night. At warm temperatures, the prion-like domain of ELF3 undergoes liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS), forming condensates that sequester ELF3 away from target promoters. This temperature-dependent phase separation effectively inactivates the EC, de-repressing PIF4 transcription. (3) H2A.Z histone variant eviction: Warm temperature causes eviction of the H2A.Z histone variant from nucleosomes at PIF4 target gene promoters, making chromatin more accessible for transcription. (4) Accumulated PIF4 directly activates YUC8 (auxin biosynthesis), TAA1, and genes in the brassinosteroid signaling pathway, promoting cell elongation. The resulting auxin increase acts through the standard TIR1/AFB-Aux/IAA-ARF pathway to drive acid growth-mediated cell wall loosening. phyB, ELF3, and H2A.Z thus function as independent thermosensors that all converge on PIF4 regulation.

questions.question: Abscisic acid biosynthesis occurs through the indirect (carotenoid) pathway. What is the rate-limiting step in ABA biosynthesis, and how is it regulated by drought stress?
options: The rate-limiting step is zeaxanthin epoxidase (ZEP), which is constitutively expressed and unresponsive to stress
ABA biosynthesis has no rate-limiting step; all enzymes increase equally under drought
The rate-limiting step is abscisic aldehyde oxidase (AAO3) in the cytoplasm, which is activated by phosphorylation under drought

The rate-limiting step is 9-cis-epoxycarotenoid dioxygenase (NCED), which cleaves 9-cis-violaxanthin/9-cis-neoxanthin to xanthoxin in plastids; NCED gene expression is rapidly and strongly induced by drought, osmotic stress, and dehydration, providing a transcriptional on-switch for ABA accumulation
questions.explanation: ABA biosynthesis via the indirect (C40 carotenoid) pathway occurs in two cellular compartments. In plastids: zeaxanthin is epoxidized to violaxanthin by ZEP (zeaxanthin epoxidase, also called ABA1), then isomerized to 9-cis-violaxanthin or converted to 9-cis-neoxanthin. The rate-limiting step is the cleavage of these 9-cis-xanthophylls by NCED (9-cis-epoxycarotenoid dioxygenase) to produce xanthoxin (C15) and a C25 apocarotenoid. In Arabidopsis, NCED3 is the major drought-responsive isoform (NCED2, NCED5, NCED6, NCED9 have roles in seeds and other tissues). NCED3 gene expression is rapidly induced (within 15-30 minutes) by drought, salt stress, and exogenous ABA treatment, increasing transcript levels 10-100 fold. This transcriptional regulation is mediated by drought-responsive transcription factors including ANAC055, ANAC072 (RD26), and AREB/ABF factors. NCED3 protein is also regulated post-translationally by subcellular relocalization (from stroma to thylakoid membrane under stress). In the cytoplasm: xanthoxin is converted to abscisic aldehyde by ABA2 (short-chain dehydrogenase/reductase), then to ABA by AAO3 (abscisic aldehyde oxidase, requiring a molybdenum cofactor supplied by ABA3/MCSU). These cytoplasmic steps are not rate-limiting under most conditions. The strong transcriptional regulation of NCED3 makes it the primary control point for stress-induced ABA accumulation.

questions.question: Photoprotection in plants involves non-photochemical quenching (NPQ) of excess light energy. What is the xanthophyll cycle, and how does it contribute to photoprotection?
options: The xanthophyll cycle converts chlorophyll a to chlorophyll b under excess light, reducing photon absorption
Xanthophyll cycling is a light-harvesting enhancement mechanism that increases photosynthetic efficiency under limiting light conditions
The xanthophyll cycle produces carotenoid antioxidants that directly quench all reactive oxygen species in the stroma

Under excess light, the thylakoid lumen becomes acidic; low pH activates violaxanthin de-epoxidase (VDE), converting violaxanthin to zeaxanthin via antheraxanthin; zeaxanthin associates with LHCII antenna proteins and PsbS to dissipate excess excitation energy as heat (qE component of NPQ), preventing photodamage to PSII reaction centers
questions.explanation: The xanthophyll cycle is a central component of the rapidly reversible, energy-dependent quenching (qE) component of NPQ. The cycle involves three carotenoid interconversions: Under excess light: (1) Excessive electron flow through the thylakoid electron transport chain leads to accumulation of protons in the thylakoid lumen, lowering lumen pH to ~5-5.5. (2) Low pH activates violaxanthin de-epoxidase (VDE), a lumenal enzyme that sequentially removes epoxide groups from violaxanthin (double-epoxide) to produce antheraxanthin (mono-epoxide) and then zeaxanthin (no epoxide). VDE requires ascorbate as reductant. (3) Zeaxanthin, in concert with the PsbS protein (a PSII subunit that acts as a lumen pH sensor via protonatable glutamate residues), reorganizes LHCII antenna complexes to create energy-dissipating states. Zeaxanthin's lower excited-state energy level (compared to violaxanthin) enables it to accept excess excitation energy from chlorophyll and dissipate it harmlessly as heat through molecular vibrations. Under low light: Zeaxanthin epoxidase (ZEP) converts zeaxanthin back to violaxanthin, restoring efficient light harvesting. The npq1 mutant (lacking VDE) and npq4 mutant (lacking PsbS) are both deficient in qE and show increased photoinhibition under fluctuating light. This photoprotective mechanism is critical for plant survival under natural light conditions, which fluctuate dramatically (sunflecks, cloud cover).

questions.question: A researcher wants to prove that the CONSTANS (CO) protein functions as a mobile signal from leaves to the shoot apical meristem to induce flowering. She expresses CO under a phloem companion cell-specific promoter (SUC2:CO) in a co mutant background. What result would disprove the hypothesis that CO protein is the mobile flowering signal?
options: The SUC2:CO plants flower at the same time as wild-type, proving CO acts in phloem companion cells
CO protein is detected in the phloem sap, proving it is the mobile signal
The SUC2:CO plants never flower, proving CO cannot function in phloem companion cells

The SUC2:CO plants flower normally, but FT mRNA is detected only in leaves (not at the meristem), while FT protein is detected at the meristem—indicating that CO activates FT transcription in leaves, and it is FT protein (not CO protein) that moves to the meristem as florigen
questions.explanation: This experiment distinguishes between two hypotheses: (1) CO protein is the mobile flowering signal (florigen), or (2) CO functions locally in leaf companion cells to activate a downstream mobile signal (FT). The critical observation that disproves CO mobility as the mechanism: if SUC2:CO rescues flowering in the co mutant (the plant flowers normally), this confirms CO functions in phloem companion cells. However, if CO protein is NOT detected at the shoot apical meristem (by immunolocalization or CO-GFP fusion), while FT protein IS detected there, this proves that CO is not the mobile signal—it acts locally to induce FT expression. The detection of FT mRNA only in leaves (not at the meristem) but FT protein at the meristem confirms that FT mRNA is transcribed in leaf companion cells and FT protein (not mRNA) is the mobile signal. This is essentially what was demonstrated experimentally: CO expression in companion cells (where it activates FT transcription) is both necessary and sufficient for photoperiodic flowering. CO protein does not move long-distance; rather, it is the FT protein (activated by CO) that travels through the phloem to the shoot apical meristem to trigger flowering. This established FT/Hd3a as the molecular identity of florigen.

questions.question: Callose deposition at plasmodesmata is a rapid defense response that restricts pathogen movement between cells. What enzyme synthesizes callose, and how is its activity regulated during defense?
options: Callose is synthesized by cellulose synthase (CESA) using the same mechanism as cellulose but with different substrate geometry
Callose is produced by mitochondrial beta-glucan synthases and secreted via exocytosis to the cell surface
Callose is imported from the apoplast through ABC transporters and deposited at plasmodesmata without any enzymatic synthesis in the cell

Callose (beta-1,3-glucan) is synthesized by callose synthase/glucan synthase-like (GSL/CalS) enzymes at the plasma membrane; their activity is rapidly induced by pathogen detection through PAMP-triggered calcium influx, MAPK cascade activation, and SA signaling, depositing callose plugs at plasmodesmata and cell wall appositions (papillae) to physically block pathogen spread
questions.explanation: Callose is a beta-1,3-glucan polymer synthesized by plasma membrane-localized callose synthase enzymes (GSL/CalS family; 12 members in Arabidopsis, with CalS1/GSL6 and CalS12/GSL5/PMR4 being most important for defense). Callose synthases use UDP-glucose as substrate and extrude the beta-1,3-glucan chain directly through the plasma membrane into the cell wall/plasmodesmatal space. During pathogen defense: (1) PAMP perception by PRRs (FLS2, CERK1, etc.) triggers rapid calcium influx through CNGC channels. (2) The calcium signal directly activates callose synthases (CalS proteins have calcium-binding domains). (3) MAPK cascade activation (MPK3/MPK6) and CDPK activation further stimulate callose deposition through transcriptional and post-translational regulation. (4) Callose is deposited at two critical locations: plasmodesmata (plugging the symplastic connections to prevent pathogen movement between cells) and cell wall appositions (papillae, formed at attempted penetration sites by powdery mildew and other pathogens). Papillae also contain hydrogen peroxide, phenolics, and antimicrobial proteins. The PMR4/CalS12 mutant (powdery mildew resistant 4) paradoxically shows ENHANCED resistance because loss of callose deposition triggers compensatory SA-dependent defense activation. SA also regulates callose synthase expression. Callose deposition is also regulated during development (sieve plate formation, pollen tube wall, cell plate formation) by different CalS family members.

questions.question: Autonomous root cap shedding (border cell release) is a feature of root growth. What signals control border cell production, and what defensive functions do border cells serve?
options: Border cells are living cells released from the root cap periphery through pectin-degrading enzyme activity; they remain viable, secrete mucilage and antimicrobial compounds (including extracellular DNA traps analogous to animal neutrophil NETs), attract beneficial microbes, and create a protective biological barrier against root pathogens
Border cells are fungal hyphae that attach to the root surface and are mistakenly identified as plant cells
Border cells are produced only under waterlogged conditions as a buoyancy mechanism
Border cells are dead cells sloughed off passively by physical abrasion as roots grow through soil
questions.explanation: Root border cells are a fascinating and underappreciated aspect of root biology. They are living, metabolically active cells that separate from the root cap periphery through the action of cell wall-modifying enzymes, particularly pectin methylesterases and pectate lyases that dissolve the middle lamella. In many species, border cells are released as individual cells; in some (Arabidopsis), they remain attached as sheets (called border-like cells). Border cells serve multiple defensive functions: (1) Mucilage secretion: Border cells secrete copious amounts of high-molecular-weight mucilage (polysaccharides, glycoproteins) that lubricates root passage through soil, maintains hydration, and traps soil particles. (2) Antimicrobial defense: Border cells secrete antimicrobial compounds including defensins, chitinases, and phytoalexins. Remarkably, border cells also release extracellular DNA (exDNA) that forms web-like structures in the mucilage, functioning as extracellular traps (ETs) analogous to neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in animal innate immunity. These DNA traps immobilize and kill bacterial and fungal pathogens. DNase treatment eliminates this defense. (3) Pathogen decoy: Border cells can attract and trap root-parasitic nematodes, diverting them from the root tip. (4) Beneficial microbe recruitment: Border cell exudates selectively attract PGPR and mycorrhizal fungi. Border cell production is regulated by auxin (promotes production), NO, and environmental signals. The root cap maintains border cell production throughout root growth.

questions.question: The Green Revolution semi-dwarf wheat and rice varieties have altered gibberellin signaling. What specific mutations confer the semi-dwarf phenotype in Green Revolution varieties?
options: Semi-dwarf wheat (Rht-B1b, Rht-D1b) carries gain-of-function mutations in DELLA proteins (making them GA-insensitive and constitutive growth repressors), while semi-dwarf rice (sd1) carries a loss-of-function mutation in GA20ox (reducing GA biosynthesis); both result in reduced stem elongation but through different molecular mechanisms
Semi-dwarf phenotypes result from mutations in phototropin genes that reduce the phototropic elongation response
Green Revolution varieties have mutations in cellulose synthase genes that reduce cell wall extensibility
Green Revolution varieties have mutations that increase GA biosynthesis, causing negative feedback that ultimately reduces growth
questions.explanation: The Green Revolution semi-dwarf varieties that dramatically increased global food production involve two different molecular mechanisms in GA signaling: (1) Semi-dwarf wheat: The Rht (Reduced height) genes, identified by Norman Borlaug's breeding program, encode DELLA proteins (orthologs of Arabidopsis GAI/RGA). The semi-dwarfing alleles Rht-B1b and Rht-D1b carry mutations in the DELLA domain (N-terminal regulatory domain) that prevent GID1-mediated recognition and ubiquitination. These mutant DELLA proteins cannot be degraded even when GA is present, making them constitutive growth repressors. The plants are therefore GA-insensitive (not GA-deficient)—applying exogenous GA does not rescue the dwarf phenotype. The shortened stems resist lodging (falling over) under heavy grain loads and wind, increasing harvest index. (2) Semi-dwarf rice: The sd1 (semi-dwarf 1) gene encodes GA20-oxidase (GA20ox-2), a key enzyme in bioactive GA biosynthesis. The sd1 allele in IR8 rice (the 'Miracle Rice') carries a loss-of-function deletion that reduces GA20ox activity, lowering bioactive GA levels. Unlike wheat, sd1 rice is GA-deficient, not GA-insensitive—applying exogenous GA rescues the normal height. Both mechanisms reduce stem elongation while maintaining or improving grain yield, since the saved energy from reduced vegetative growth is redirected to grain filling (higher harvest index).

questions.question: Peptide hormones are increasingly recognized as important plant signaling molecules. What role does the CLE (CLAVATA3/EMBRYO SURROUNDING REGION) peptide family play in shoot and root meristem regulation?
options: CLV3 (CLAVATA3) peptide is secreted from stem cells in the shoot apical meristem, perceived by CLV1/CLV2/CRN receptor kinase complexes in the organizing center below, which repress WUS (WUSCHEL) transcription factor expression; WUS in turn promotes CLV3 expression, creating a negative feedback loop (CLV3-WUS) that maintains a stable stem cell population
CLE peptides are produced exclusively in roots and have no function in the shoot apical meristem
CLE peptides function as structural components of the cell wall and have no signaling role
CLE peptides promote unlimited meristem growth by activating stem cell divisions without any negative feedback
questions.explanation: The CLV3-WUS negative feedback loop is one of the most elegant regulatory circuits in plant development. In the shoot apical meristem (SAM): (1) WUS (WUSCHEL), a WOX-family homeodomain transcription factor, is expressed in the organizing center (OC, a small group of cells beneath the central zone). WUS protein moves through plasmodesmata to the central zone stem cells. (2) In stem cells, WUS activates transcription of CLV3 (CLAVATA3), a 12-amino acid CLE peptide that is secreted into the apoplast after processing from a 96-amino acid precursor. CLV3 is arabinosylated (tri-arabinosylation of a hydroxyproline residue is required for full activity). (3) Secreted CLV3 peptide is perceived by multiple receptor complexes in the OC and surrounding cells: CLV1 (an LRR-RLK), CLV2-CRN/SOL2 (an LRR-RLP and pseudokinase heterodimer), and RPK2/TOAD2. (4) CLV3 perception activates these receptors, which signal through MAPK cascades and the POL/PLL phosphatase to REPRESS WUS transcription in the OC. (5) Reduced WUS leads to reduced CLV3, relieving WUS repression—this negative feedback maintains homeostasis. If stem cells are lost, CLV3 decreases, WUS increases, and new stem cells are specified. If excess stem cells form, CLV3 increases, WUS decreases, and excess cells differentiate. CLV3 mutants have enlarged meristems (fasciated stems) due to unrestrained WUS activity. In root meristems, CLE40 peptide plays an analogous role through ACR4/CLV1 receptors regulating WOX5 expression.

questions.question: Nitric oxide (NO) is a gaseous signaling molecule in plants with roles in defense, development, and stress responses. How is NO produced in plants, and what are its major signaling mechanisms?
options: NO is produced through multiple routes: nitrate reductase (NIA1/NIA2) reduces nitrite to NO under certain conditions, and non-enzymatic reduction of nitrite occurs at low pH; NO signals by S-nitrosylation of cysteine residues on target proteins (including NPR1, TIR1, RBOHD, and PYR/PYL ABA receptors), modulating their activity in defense, hormone signaling, and stress responses
Plants do not produce NO; all NO in plant tissues comes from soil bacteria in the rhizosphere
NO is produced only by mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase as a byproduct of respiration and has no intentional signaling function
NO in plants is produced exclusively by a canonical nitric oxide synthase (NOS) identical to animal iNOS
questions.explanation: Nitric oxide (NO) is an important gaseous signaling molecule in plants, though its biosynthesis is less clearly defined than in animals (which have dedicated NOS enzymes). In plants, NO is produced through multiple routes: (1) Nitrate reductase (NR/NIA)-dependent: NIA1 and NIA2 (cytoplasmic nitrate reductases that normally reduce NO3- to NO2-) can also reduce nitrite (NO2-) to NO under conditions of high nitrite, low oxygen, or specific post-translational regulation. This is a major source of NO in plants. (2) Polyamine/hydroxylamine oxidation: Oxidation of polyamines and hydroxylamines by amine oxidases. (3) Non-enzymatic: At acidic pH (e.g., in the apoplast or aleurone acidified compartments), nitrite can be non-enzymatically reduced to NO, particularly in the presence of ascorbic acid. (4) A plant NOS-like activity has been detected but no canonical NOS gene has been identified in plant genomes. NO signals primarily through: S-nitrosylation—the covalent modification of cysteine thiol groups to form S-nitrosothiols (SNOs). Key targets include NPR1 (S-nitrosylation promotes oligomerization, keeping NPR1 inactive in the absence of pathogen attack), TIR1 (S-nitrosylation enhances auxin receptor binding), RBOHD (S-nitrosylation at Cys890 inhibits its activity, providing negative feedback on the ROS burst), and PYR1/PYL ABA receptors (S-nitrosylation reduces ABA binding). GSNO reductase (GSNOR1) regulates overall S-nitrosylation levels by metabolizing GSNO (S-nitrosoglutathione), the major NO reservoir. gsnor1 mutants have elevated SNO levels and compromised defense responses.

questions.question: The SCFTIR1/AFB auxin signaling pathway is mechanistically similar to which other plant hormone signaling pathways in its use of F-box proteins to degrade transcriptional repressors?
options: SCF(COI1) in jasmonate signaling (degrades JAZ repressors) and SCF(SLY1/GID2) in gibberellin signaling (degrades DELLA repressors) both use the same core logic: hormone acts as molecular glue promoting F-box protein-repressor interaction, leading to ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of the repressor to activate transcription
Only the ethylene pathway shares this mechanism, with EIN2 acting as the F-box protein
No other plant hormone pathway uses F-box-mediated repressor degradation; auxin signaling is unique in this regard
The brassinosteroid pathway through BRI1 kinase uses the same F-box mechanism to degrade BES1
questions.explanation: A remarkable convergent feature of plant hormone signaling is the repeated use of the SCF (Skp1-Cullin-F-box) E3 ubiquitin ligase pathway to control hormone-dependent gene expression through degradation of transcriptional repressors. Three major pathways share this logic: (1) Auxin: SCF(TIR1/AFB) + IAA as molecular glue -> degrades Aux/IAA repressors -> releases ARF transcription factors. TIR1 is the F-box protein. (2) Jasmonate: SCF(COI1) + JA-Ile as molecular glue -> degrades JAZ repressors -> releases MYC2 and other TFs. COI1 is the F-box protein. (3) Gibberellin: SCF(SLY1/GID2) + GA-GID1 as molecular glue -> degrades DELLA repressors -> releases PIFs and other TFs. SLY1 is the F-box protein. In each case, the hormone serves as a molecular adhesive that stabilizes the interaction between the F-box protein and its target repressor, promoting polyubiquitination and 26S proteasomal degradation. The strigolactone pathway also uses this mechanism: D14 (receptor) + SL -> interaction with MAX2 (F-box) -> degrades D53/SMXL repressors. This convergent evolution of the derepression model (hormone removes repressor to activate signaling) is a hallmark of plant hormone biology, contrasting with animal steroid signaling where hormones typically directly activate their receptors as transcription factors.

questions.question: Tropism versus nastic movement: what is the fundamental distinction between these two categories of plant movement, and how does this relate to the directionality of the stimulus?
options: Tropisms are always growth-mediated while nastic movements are always turgor-mediated; the direction of the stimulus is irrelevant to the classification

Tropisms are directional responses where the direction of movement is determined by the direction of the stimulus (e.g., toward or away from light), while nastic movements are non-directional responses where the stimulus triggers a predetermined movement regardless of the direction from which the stimulus comes
Tropisms only occur in stems while nastic movements only occur in leaves
There is no fundamental distinction; tropism and nastic movement are interchangeable terms for the same phenomena
questions.explanation: The fundamental distinction between tropisms and nastic movements lies in the relationship between the direction of the stimulus and the direction of the response. Tropisms are directional growth responses where the direction of plant growth is determined by the direction of the environmental stimulus. Examples: phototropism (bending toward light), gravitropism (bending relative to gravity vector), thigmotropism (directional growth response to touch, as in tendril coiling around a support). If the light source is moved, the direction of bending changes accordingly. Nastic movements are non-directional responses where the stimulus triggers a stereotyped movement pattern regardless of the direction from which the stimulus comes. The direction of movement is determined by the anatomy of the responding organ (e.g., asymmetric motor cells in the pulvinus), not by the stimulus direction. Examples: thigmonasty (Mimosa folding upon touch from any direction), nyctinasty (sleep movements driven by circadian clock), thermonasty (tulip petal opening in warmth). Nastic movements can be growth-mediated (epinasty involves differential growth) or turgor-mediated (Mimosa pulvinar movements), so the growth/turgor distinction does not define the category. Similarly, some tropisms involve turgor changes (hydrotropism in roots involves turgor-mediated bending). The key criterion is purely whether the response direction depends on the stimulus direction.

questions.question: Auxin maximum formation at sites of lateral organ initiation requires both polar auxin transport and local auxin biosynthesis. How does PIN1-mediated auxin convergence at the shoot apical meristem (SAM) determine phyllotaxis (leaf arrangement)?
options: Leaves form at random positions on the SAM, and phyllotactic patterns are an illusion of uniform growth rates

PIN1 proteins in the L1 layer of the SAM orient their polarity toward sites of high auxin concentration (up-the-gradient model), creating convergence points where auxin accumulates; each new auxin maximum specifies a new leaf primordium, while existing primordia deplete auxin from their surroundings, creating inhibitory fields that position the next maximum at the farthest point from existing primordia
Phyllotaxis is determined exclusively by mechanical stresses in the meristem dome, with no involvement of auxin
Gibberellin, not auxin, determines leaf placement through DELLA-mediated regulation of cell division planes
questions.explanation: Phyllotaxis (the regular geometric arrangement of leaves around the stem) is determined by auxin-mediated self-organization at the shoot apical meristem. The mechanism involves: (1) PIN1 polarity dynamics in the L1 (outermost) layer of the SAM: PIN1 proteins in L1 cells orient toward neighboring cells with the highest auxin concentration (the 'up-the-gradient' or 'with-the-flux' model). This creates convergence points where auxin accumulates from surrounding cells. (2) Auxin maximum formation: At convergence points, auxin concentration exceeds a threshold that triggers the auxin-mediated signaling cascade (TIR1-Aux/IAA-MP/ARF5), activating genes for organ initiation. MP/MONOPTEROS (ARF5) is essential—mp mutants fail to initiate lateral organs. (3) Auxin depletion: As a primordium develops, it becomes an auxin sink that drains auxin from surrounding tissue through PIN1-mediated inward transport. This creates an auxin-depleted zone (inhibitory field) around each existing primordium. (4) New primordium positioning: The next auxin maximum forms at the point farthest from all existing depletion zones, which in a circular meristem generates the golden angle (~137.5 degrees) characteristic of spiral phyllotaxis. This is predicted by computational models combining PIN1 dynamics with auxin diffusion and transport. (5) Local auxin biosynthesis (YUCCA genes) at incipient primordia further sharpens the auxin maximum. The robustness of phyllotactic patterns across species reflects the self-organizing mathematical properties of this auxin transport system.
